comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Certainly not Hickson Road! Got my thinking cap on trying to work out this one! The railway trestle has me tossed!

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: I can see Caledonian Hotel that was on King St, Darling Harbour

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] You're right, the photo is in fact a shot of Day Street, between King Street and Erskine Street. The street we see on the right is Slip Street. Behind the photographer the tram lines turn into Erskine Street before entering a balloon loop using New and Shelley Streets. The tram lines are the city end of the Watson's Bay line which was converted from Cable operation to electric traction between 1902 and 1905. My guess would be that the photo was perhaps taken soon after the opening of the electric line along Day Street - before the conversion the cable tram terminated in King Street.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: It looks too hilly to be Hickson Road

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The SMH on 25 October 1902 reports Mr Walter Saxton leaving the business he worked for, to start his own contracting business.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: behind that iron truss,   you can see the Pyrmont bridge crossing over Day St a block further down,  including the big fat toadstool pillars which still exist.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Plan J of the 1900 resumption plan covers this neighbourhood,   and in 1900,  it looked very different.  If that is when the drawing actually refers to.    Day Street did not exist then between Slip Street and Market St/Pyrmont Bridge.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Plan 145 of the Fire Underwriters maps also covers this area,  and shows two steel bridges over the street connecting Howard Smith's wharf to two warehouses in Sussex Street.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The photographer is standing right outside the Bristol Arms hotel,  to his or her left.
